author: PAUL SCHWARTZ
title: The cross-country report: Local runners make their college choices - Boys Cross-Country
text:
Many of North Jersey’s top cross-country and track athletes are starting to commit to the colleges where they’ll be continuing their athletic careers, in many cases before they’ve even competed in a major event in their senior year.
Colin and Will Daly of River Dell announced Wednesday their selection of the University of Pennsylvania with Colin likely to study economics and Will engineering.
The twins had made visits to Duke and Wake Forest and had planned to go to Princeton this weekend, but canceled that trip when they reached their decision.
"At first we thought we might go our separate ways," said Will. "But once we started to go to the visits together we figured the chances would be good that we’d stay together.
"We decided after our Penn visit that we knew where we wanted to go, and after thinking about it for about two weeks, we decided to commit now rather than wait."
Even though the Dalys haven’t run a serious race yet this year (they’ll even skip Saturday’s Shore Invitational and debut at the Manhattan Invitational on Oct. 10), they’re comfortable with their decision.
"We have so much faith in [Penn] coach [Steve] Dolan and his staff that they will do as good a job as anywhere else in the country training us," said Colin. "And we love the campus."
She doesn’t run cross-country, but Northern Highlands senior Hilary McElwain also made her verbal commitment this week, as the intermediate hurdler/long sprinter committed to Lehigh, where she’ll join longtime rival Noreen Byrne, who graduated from River Dell last year.
"The coaches and athletes were really nice and they have a great engineering program," said McElwain, who helped the Highlanders share the Group 3 state title last year and came within a spot of earning a state Meet of Champions medal in the intermediates.
"I’ve been looking at Lehigh since my sophomore year and even though Bucknell was interested too, I went with my gut and will sign when I can in November," she said.
Decision time is drawing near for two other North Jersey distance stars: two-time Bergen County cross-country champion Patrick Sullivan of Don Bosco and multi state Meet of Champions medalist Julia Guerra of Indian Hills.
Guerra has the easier road, as she has completed her official visits to Wake Forest, the University of Washington and Penn State, and expects to make a decision in the next couple of weeks.
"I didn’t think the visits would be so tiring," said Guerra. "And shopping for schools requires so many decisions to make. But I’m going to decide what’s best for me academically, running and a place where I’ll be happiest even if I can’t run."
Sullivan’s top choices appear to be West Point and the Air Force Academy, although the Clarkstown, N.Y. senior also might visit American University and the University of Kentucky.
Choosing a service academy requires a physical and passing a fitness test in addition to the traditional application and also requires a nomination from his Congressman, Senators or other eligible nominator.
"I’m trying to get my application complete by the end of the month," said Sullivan, who will run at Manhattan on Oct. 10. "I’ve done my official visits to West Point and the Air Force Academy, but now its time to concentrate on getting the applications done and running."
